pros: - if you can lower your head, keep your mouth shut then this is a place to just collect paycheck - if you don't want a career growth and are happy where you are, then this may be the place. - if you agree with whatever your boss says, then this is the place.
cons: - poor management and no leadership direction. No accountability from the leadership. If they can pass the bucket to you, they will. They are not in line with what they preach such as the ICARE values. No innovation is encouraged or allowed. Although, the company provides an annual training in which they encourage innovation, unparalleled service, etc. - if you work in IT, this is a dead-end job place. No real in-class training and no IT conference will be approved by the managers; however, they would be the ones going to these conferences. Unfortunately, they often brought nothing back to the team to help the team/department to improve or at least learn the best practice of what the industry are doing out there. - If you remain long in IT, you will not learn anything new. Most people kept to themselves and little collaboration existed even within the same team. This is not a culture of team collaboration and team work. Everyone is for himself and herself. - There is no career growth in IT.

review_title: Top Notch Hospital, Amateur Hour Research Institute
pros: They take good care of their employees. Salary and benefits are strong. Lots of employee assistance and resources, perks and special thanks through events and bonuses. Methodist deserves its reputation as one of the best hospitals and best employers in Houston.
cons: The hospital is great, the research institute is another story. In fact, it is a total dumpster fire. For as good as the hospital's leadership is, the research institute leadership is terrible. The CEO is a snake oil salesman control freak and the directors are members in his cult of personality. The people who actually do the work are overworked, under resourced, and micromanaged like crazy. They love to talk about how great and values-focused they are but it is all talk. Superstar docs get whatever they want and anyone else gets thrown under the bus to make sure the gravy train keeps rolling. They've had major turnover problems and there shouldn't be any mystery why. No consequences for the obviously inept leadership though, just band aids and spin. Their reputation is garbage outside of Houston because the horror stories, waste and low standards are no longer much of a secret. Some day soon all the chickens will come home to roost and you'll not want to be at Houston Methodist Research Institute when they do.

review_title: Decent place to work but be ready to float often and beneath your your scope
pros:
Prestige
Seem to care about employees
Give quarterly bonus
cons:
1. When injured on the job, will find every reason not to take responsibility 
2. Rather than adequately staff units with fully employed personnel, or have a float pool for times of unplanned shortages, nursing staff are floated to any, an every unit in the hospital, to do any and every job, including PCAs and unit secretaries. Like, what does a NICU nurse know about handling the workload of a medsurg PCA? But you are floated all the same, to units where you aren’t appreciated. It would be okay if it was once in a while, but every 2 weeks, to the point where we don’t even want to come to work anymore. 

Also, when you are on call, you are on call for the whole hospital (not just your unit), so you can be called in at anytime to go be a sitter for a. newly arrived patient ,for example, at ungodly hours of day or night. This does nothing for morale, and is the reason many of us have/ are planning to exit.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Houston, TX
pros: People you work with are nice and professional. Hospital seems to care about employees. Bonuses for hand hygiene.
cons:
Hospital culture seems to be kind of cult like.

Sometimes patients get left behind. 
For example ER MDs only have to see a certain number of patients during their shift so if a patient comes in at end of their quota with a long tedious work up the doctor will put them off until relief comes in. Most of the time it’s not during an emergency but I’ve seen it during times in which the patient may have cauda equina and that is a medical emergency that can have serious implications on a patient’s ability to void long term. It’s not as serious as a heart attack or stroke but still has long lasting effects on the patient if not dealt with quickly. Methodist also has a special program for big donors so they treat some people better than others in medical care, which is definitely not right. They even have special customer service individuals that meet with these high paying donors during their stay and are alerted to this fact when they enter the hospital which seems like it may be a violation of HIPA.
Management doesn’t understand mandatory overtime laws in Texas and hold over against their will with meetings after their shift but before report can be given.

job_title: Prefer Not To Say in Houston, TX
pros: Great organization, hard work is being rewarded, amazing teammates, good work life balance.
cons:
This review is about HR function of our otherwise great organization. HR may be doing a satisfactory job with the technical side (FMLA, STD). However, the disaster comes when HR generalists try to do everything: from the job codes cleaning to trying to be a middle man in conflict resolution. The latter is a farce and “dog and pony” show. Even if middle management is 100% wrong, and it’s obvious as day and night to many, HM generalists will side with the management and will not stop management’s obnoxious, insulting behavior. They will not follow up, they will not provide strategies for the parties as promised. They need education and training on conflict resolution. But most of all, they need to have integrity and accountability that they lack. People who work for HM for 30+ years are wise to note that the role of HM HR is only to protect HR. 
Is it time to restructure the processes that are not working?

review_title: Employee's overworked, only patient perspective and money matters
job_title: Patient Care Assistant (PCA) in The Woodlands, TX
pros:
Good benefits
Decent pay
Co-workers generally good to work with
cons:
Employee's are just a number, we're used and abused. You're often set up for failure and then they get mad at you when you don't produce a miracle.
Ex: Snowpocalypse in Feb 2021 Methodist waited till 4pm to tell us we were on lockdown. Every other hospital in the area called in their disaster team the day before and were well prepared. Houston Methodist however...... We were not allowed to stay at the hotel across the street, nor go to the store for necessities. We were not allowed to leave for anything, we could not even go to our car to get supplies from it without a security escort. The "beds" they provided were cots (many broke during night, or were already broken when received (and you were packed shoulder to shoulder in conference rooms with other employees)), or exam tables that were about as comfortable as sleeping on the hard floor. The "food" was worse than prison food. Spaghetti with a tsp of red sauce for dinner, decent breakfast, lunch white bread w/tiny spoonful of pb&j with Oreos or chips. People who could not eat that food went without eating. Many people did not even get an opportunity to shower. If we did not have someone available to bring us supplies, we were SOL. Me along with many others slept in the scrubs we had worn all day, and had to continue to wear them the next day for our shift.
All they care about is money, patient perspective, and their HCAP scores.
They take away patient rights and try to convince them that their way is helping them. Ex: Completely alert and oriented patient not on any altering meds, stable vitals, ambulatory, and not a fall risk still MUST have a bed alarm on. If they refuse, it gets escalated to management who then comes and attempts to either brainwash or break them down into allowing the bed alarm. I have had patients from prison say that staying in this hospital is worse than prison. They boast about having a "patient centric" culture, but don't actually care what the patient wants or needs. Patients are often discharged too early so they can make room for another patient, only to have the previous patient come back a couple days to weeks later for the same issue that was not fully resolved in the first place.
Methodist wants things their way, and only their way with no regard for what others think or feel.
We're overworked with little reward.
If you get injured on the job, they will find every reason not to support you or handle it. They somehow turn the blame to you so that it is not their responsibility.
No support from upper management, they're honestly just a bunch of snakes. They truly follow the "customer is always right" so you get abused on the daily from patients with little support. Management just askes "What could you have done better?"
They don't actually want diversity and inclusion, or follow their values. It's all for show to draw people in and make themselves look good so they can make more money. If you don't fit in their little box, they will find a reason to fire you.
Any research or discoveries you make while working there, Houston Methodist owns and will take credit for. They legit make you sign a contract for that.

pros:

cons:
Patient care is less important than the HCAPS scores

Often have broken equipment that they won't fix (But they can buy iPads for every patient room)
They make promises but don't follow through. (Ex: They say they value your opinion and door is always open but when you go to talk to them, if they don't agree they immediately shut you down and don't listen to you. They claim raises are merit based, but in reality everyone across the board just gets a 2% raise which is like 30 cents.)
Patients have very little freedom of choice during their stay.
One person does something wrong and a patient complains, everyone gets punished.
Instead of correcting the problematic employee, they implement procedures that go across the board for everyone. This makes the good employees job more difficult sometimes, and is also a moral killer.

job_title: Research Assistant II in Houston, TX
pros:
The people that I work with directly are understanding, helpful, creative and extremely intelligent.
 The research facilities are pretty good, though many cutting edge research technologies are notably absent (Microisolator CMP facilities, CyTOF, NGS, High-res MS, cell culture validation services)
cons:
* Cliff vesting schedule for retirement is not great, and management fees are sky high. 
* vision coverage is a joke.
* dental coverage is mediocre
* rx coverage heavily restricts pharmacy choice for certain prescriptions
* PTO is limited, and incentivizes sick employees to come to work, which has caused me to get sick on more than one occasion.
* Work/life balance is bad. Overwork is a serious problem, and is unaddressed even if you bring it up. My salary is competitive for the area, but when distributed over the hours I work, calculates out to less than minimum wage. I was mocked when I brought it up. Pushing employees to work senselessly long hours is common. 
* Little to no diversity in my department, which only hires and retains chinese men. 
* Onboarding timeline makes a smooth departure very difficult.

review_title: It its a good place to work
pros: Pay is pretty good, and the unit I work on seems to be very good about giving time off.  We have pretty good Healthcare provided to us. If we have anything done in the Methodist hospital it is free of charge to us, the employees.  They give bonuses on a regular basis for things that should be the norm as hand hygiene and customer service, but it is nice to get them. They are not super big bonuses usually one hundred to three hundred dollars. I work on a pretty small unit which is nice we sort of have a feeling of family and I think Methodist overall has that feeling.
cons: There are a lot of changes going on at the Hospital and upper management says they don't know what is to happen with the employees in my unit. Am I actually expected to believe that they are spending millions of dollars and they don't have any idea? Please!!!  There is also a descrepency when raises are given, it seems to me at times it is not whether or not you are doing a good job it is who you are in good with, if you are good friends with your manger/supervisor.  My raises have been fair, but I do see people who get by doing little to nothing and are allowed to to poor jobs. When you go to mangement about their performance and how it effects you they tell you to handle the situation, and that doesn't always work, especially if these people are still receiveing a pay increase.

review_title: Just like all companies these days: do more with less.
pros: Generally, this hospital is good. I have been a patient here and have received good medical care.
cons:
They have instituted the "skin" investment in the health insurance benefits. The quality of the healthcare benefits has been reduced. It seems that all they see is $. This motivates everything they do and the quality of care is diminished as a result.  

Many of the perks are being slowly dismantled.  Bonus structures are changing, too.  It is too cutthroat.  

Some of the other postings here mention that directors, managers, etc are selected based on their degrees rather than experience.  I find it ridiculous to put someone in charge of an entire department when they have NO medical or clinical experience but they get the job because they have an MBA.  CLUELESS!  

I am looking for another position.  I am also tired of my manager telling everyone they should be thankful they have a job.  Companies should be thankful they have intelligent, hardworking people.

job_title: Senior Billing Specialist in Houston, TX
pros: The Clinic setting, everyone I worked with was so cool and awesome from the Doctors, Hospital Directors, and  to the staff. A very special team and the patients were great, I truly miss them. I didn't work in the same location as my assigned management, just fyi. Methodist as a facility and employer was GREAT, I worked for the PO Organization and only had problems with them.
cons: My manager was clueless on the true functions and responsibilites of the clinic and had no understanding what so ever. He never fully investigated anything, only listened to one person which in fact was very untruthful, we have since parted ways, but HR knew he was wrong which I brought up a complaint against him. They were very supportive for the most part during the process. I will always love Methodist as a whole just hope the good hard working employees realize and learn they have rights and should stand up for themselves when being bullied out of a job by a manager.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Houston, TX

review_title: Houston Methodist Hospital in the Houston Texas Medical Center
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sugar Land, TX
pros: I had the pleasure of working at Houston Methodist for six years and will always think of it as one of the best places to work in Houston.  The pride the Administration, hospital staff, and physicians  took in evaluating the latest and  and most up to date outcomes data, equipment upgrades and care methodologies for the  patients, served to highlight the fact that patient safety was always priority one for the organization, as it should be!
cons: New department leaders need more training and follow-up during their first year with input obtained from reporting staff, in order to better understand the hospital's mission and the Houston Methodist way of doing things, before implementing work strategies and processes from their originating institutions, which do not coincide  with the organization's vision.

pros:
* I CARE culture that is visible throughout the organization (multi-million dollar employee assistance fund set-up after Hurricane Harvey to help employees who suffered damages from the storm; everyone received a "whole" paycheck for the week of the storm whether they were able to make it to work or not; those who did make it to work received $100 bonus for each day during the worst of the storm; counseling and support for those impacted by the storm; opportunities to volunteer in the community on an annual basis while being paid to do so)
* Excellent benefits (DCP with min. of 3% of salary deposited annually plus 2% match on 403b; great medical/dental/vision; quarterly pt. satisfaction perf. bonuses plus other occasional bonuses; generous PTO; robust Wellness program)
cons: Large organization but department/division/entity cohesiveness helps make it still feel like a family

review_title: The Methodist Hospital System - Advanced Degrees, Minimal Mid-Level Leadership
job_title: Director In IT in Houston, TX
pros:
The salary was comparable to other healthcare facilities in the greater Houston area, but their benefits really were outstanding.  

Senior management at The Methodist Hospital system truly had a vision for what they wanted Methodist to be, and they did a good job of communicating that to the rest of the management team and to all employees across the company.  

One of the best things about working for Methodist was the fact that the company had outstanding fiscal management over the past few years, resulting in a fiscal portfolio that was next to none.  If you needed funding to do something, as long as you could make your case and the case resulted in efficiency or better, safer patient care...chances are you would get the funding you needed.
cons:
Being an academic teaching hospital, there was an overwhelming expectation of management having advanced degrees, regardless of the area of study the degree was in.  This was never so evident as when a person was promoted to a directorship in the Information Technology department when he had a Master's of Theology, but one of our better leaders who had a military background was demoted because he only had an associates degree (but was much more competent). 

Very little attention was paid to the skills that it takes to lead, and although "advanced degrees" were required for management, once someone attained that degree and was in their position, there was no real expectation for continued learning throughout that person's lifetime.  This fact results in a lot of "stagnant" leaders in the organization that are really just dead wood.

pros: They have amazing benefits. Their ICARE values really prove that patients matter to the company. It feels like a caring and family-oriented environment. The company focusing on being healthy and rewarding you for it. There are opportunities for bonuses -- simply for keeping good hygiene amongst other things.

cons: I have been employed with the Research Institute for over 7 years now.  The main mantra of HM is the pillars of the ICARE values (Integrity, Compassion, Accountability, Respect, Excellence).  It is apparent that this only goes for employees.  Over the past 3 years it has been apparent that there will need to be a change in management and leadership.  Management of our department has gotten away with all sorts of retaliation  when it comes to reporting issues to HR.  HR is only out to cover for the company and the leadership of the institution.  HR are a bunch of lazy do-nothings when it comes to helping employees resolves issues within their departments.  They talk a big game during the orientations that the employee will always be taken serious on issues but it is funny that the only group that is ever right is your manager even when they are caught in a lie.  There is no such thing as anonymity when it comes to reporting issues.  You can report an issue and they will turn it around on the employee and either write them up or try and terminate them based on these actions.  After our annual employee survey came back with horrendous results they came in and interviewed everyone and gave the feedback to the manager and director.  There was not change in behavior or action in our department.  There have been over 4 people leave or transfer out in the last 8 months.  But for some reason this is not a red flag for this group.  One of the things that is very apparent is the experience that the leadership has in RI, and that is basically none.  If this was the leadership of a corporation that needed to see results they would have been gone 4 years ago.  I understand working for the hospital is a different story and is a great place to work,  but steer clear the RI.  I am currently looking for something else

review_title: Don't assume all departments fit the top 100 places to work-
pros: Good benefits and overall orientation to the hospital environment.  Methodist does really care about serving the patient and guests in a superior manner.
cons:
An incomplete job description caused a devastating life experience.

I was terminated after working there 6 weeks because I  was unable to perform job duties that were never listed on the job description. I resigned from another position with a company where I had  full time employment and benefits and had worked for 18 months.
I went to work for Methodist only to be unceremoniously terminated because I did not possess skills that were not in the job description I signed when I signed my offer letter.  Management could have worked with me in terms of another position in the institution or trained me.  I  have excellent experience for the position and a college degree. 
I should have known better because there had been a great deal of turnover in this department.  I was not given any severance, extended medical benefits or notice.  

After receiving the news I was told to call an HR representative. No HR representative was present when I was terminated.  After leaving several messages for HR to return my call, no one has ever returned my call.  Management seemed most interested in having me sign a confidentiality agreement.

I would suggest if you are considering employment with Methodist that you fully investigate your
job duties and how much turnover there has been in the position previously.  Ask the interviewer
to explain why the changes  occurred.  Then ask to interview with another manager in the department to get a complete picture.
I have worked for a top 100 company before (my previous employer) and Methodist Hospital Houston is not a top 100 company to work for.
